content:
I've just reformatted:
* some constants originally formatted as variables, and
* some variables originally formatted as constants.

I've also deleted all output examples in Output section.
I have set the difficulty and tags.

Solved independently. (compared solution lengths and gasped--you people ought to learn Haskell) Side note: implementing a single PAIR wasn't necessary. I'm not removing it from the problem statement, let that be an easter egg. :-D

Edited a *lot*. What I remember:
* moves the worked example back in the statement
* lots of minor presentation and typography
* constraints and specs normalized.

I'd have approved it and claimed my 15XP for the effort, but someone did it while I was editing.

FUCK YOU ALL, LAST TIME I'M SPENDING TIME AND EFFORT TO IMPROVE STUFF.

The current layout is very inconvenient.  When I want to actually start writing code, I head for the input/output section. But they're currently split apart by pages (!) of problem statement including examples. Very unreadable.

(about ROYAL_FLUSH: I agree with removing it from the specs, it *is* redundant. But poker players might miss it; I'd include its omission as a note)

IMHO, the current constraints aren't. WinningPlayerId is an output specification; the card ordering is an integral part of the problem statement.
What *would* be a reasonable constraint is that the hands are well-formed (i.e., mostly, no duplicate cards).

I just re-reviewed my comments on this puzzle after 7 months of inactivity, and I am still convinced that the rules concerning the untested ROYAL_FLUSH were unnecessary, so I have removed them from the problem statement.

Okay. So I took the time to go through and solve this one today. It's a fun puzzle. I have a few comments / suggestions, though.

1) I guess I'm not an expert on Holdem. I didn't realize that an Ace can be low for the purposes of a straight. You make passing mention of this in the last sentence of your statement, but it's not at all obvious. I think this should be spelled out more clearly.

2) Related: The description of STRAIGHT_FLUSH states that it has no Ace. This is not strictly true, since it can contain a low ace, and in fact Test 4 expects a straight flush with an Ace in it.

3) There are no tests or validators that expect either a PAIR or a ROYAL_FLUSH. You can code a solution that passes all tests and validators but never detects a ROYAL_FLUSH situation.

Just noticed Bazek got in with a Poker proposal just before me, so kudos to him for suggesting it first.

Hopefully there's still merit in this proposal, as it's both slightly different (full 7 card input for Texas Holdem which makes it trickier) and there are full instructions for non-poker players.

The test cases have been designed to throw in a bunch of edge cases that a na√Øve solution would struggle with, e.g. 76543 vs 5432A etc.

Thanks for the feedback - very helpful.

Good spot RE: the straight flush with the low ace. The code and tests are correct, the Statement is incorrect. I was trying to condense/simplify the statement into minimal words and chose a poor description for that one.

RE: the validators, I agree that it's possible to pass with an incomplete solution, but isn't that always the case? I'm unfortunately limited to 8 tests/validators. My thinking was that I didn't want to introduce anything 'new' in the validators not already seen in the tests, e.g. imagine if you failed due to Ace-Low straight but in a validator with no feedback - that'd be hard to spot/fix. So I've focused on capturing the trickiest scenarios to make a good test for someone having an honest/complete crack at the problem, rather than being comprehensive on the hand types. I would expect for example that any solution capable of determining which straight is best would find pairs or royal flushes easy to distinguish.

Does that make sense? Given that, would you rather have complete hands covered, or as-is?

EDIT: Statement has been changed.

Ah yes, sorry. I meant to revisit this but was distracted by some work that came up. I'm happy for it to be the other way, I'll just need to find a free weekend to adjust and test my own code solution.
Moreover, "DRAW" doesn't fit the output specification.
Sorry if you've wasted your time. I'm not sure who finished it, but thanks to everyone that contributed.

Agreed. I remember at the time battling with the max character count, so conceded that it would work as long as there was enough info to derive the full rules from the information presented overall.  This might change when removing the Royal Flush, freeing up enough characters in the appropriate places. When I redo it I'll bear this in mind.

Agreed. I don't think that anything needs to change in terms of tests. After thinking about it a bit more, I'm wondering if maybe it's worth removing ROYAL_FLUSH from consideration at all. There's only a semantic distinction between it and STRAIGHT_FLUSH, and it's never tested. I think it adds unnecessary complexity to an already complex problem. Think about it.
